title: Lindsay Graham invites Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani to his own Ukraine 'corruption' investigation
text:
Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham is launching his own probe of 'corruption' in Ukraine – and has invited President Trump's lawyer Rudy Giuliani to testify as his star witness.

The move, if it ever came to fruition, would put one of the president's most impassioned defenders in the spotlight – while also exposing him to questioning by senators about his mysterious meetings with a former Ukrainian prosecutor and his business dealings while representing the president.

The South Carolina Republican and fierce Trump defender Lindsey Graham announced the investigation Tuesday as the Trump administration ordered a key witness in the Ukraine affair not to appear as scheduled before the House Intelligence Committee.

Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham has 'invited' Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani (left) to testify about 'corruption' in Ukraine

With the U.S. ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland sidelined in his desire to appear and answer questions, cable TV regular Giuliani will get the chance to air his claims of Ukrainian corruption that he wants aired. President Trump in a July 25 call repeatedly asks Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to contact Giuliani and seeks an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter.

'I have heard on numerous occasions disturbing allegations by Rudy Giuliani about corruption in Ukraine and the many improprieties surrounding the firing of former Prosecutor General Viktor Shokin,' said Graham in a statement and on Twitter.

'Given the House of Representatives’ behavior, it is time for the Senate to inquire about corruption and other improprieties involving Ukraine. Therefore I will offer to Mr. Giuliani the opportunity to come before the Senate Judiciary Committee to inform the Committee of his concerns,' he wrote.

Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham said it was time for the Senate to inquire about 'corruption and other improprieties involving Ukraine'

Giuliani is a regular guest on cable TV, and now could get to try speaking under oath before the Senate Judiciary Committee

The Trump administration refused to let U.S. ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland to testify to the House on Tuesday

Graham's statement came after Trump ripped the Intel panel as a 'kangaroo court,' saying he would otherwise 'love' for Sondland to cooperate.

'I would love to send Ambassador Sondland, a really good man and great American, to testify, but unfortunately he would be testifying before a totally compromised kangaroo court, where Republican’s rights have been taken away, and true facts are not allowed out for the public,' the president Tweeted.

Graham did not make any reference to his committee investigating a whistle-blower's allegations that President Trump abused his office by pushing the Ukrainians to investigate a political opponent.

Graham is a frequent golf partner of president Trump's who on Monday called the president's sudden decision to withdraw troops from Syria amid a looming Turkish invasion 'a stain on America's honor' and 'a disaster in the making.'

Giuliani told CNN he will still have to deal with matters of 'privilege.'

'I might be able to do it without discussing privileged information,' he said.

Giuliani has repeatedly pushed a narrative that Vice President Joe Biden pushed for the firing of a Ukrainian prosecutor in order to help his son, Hunter. Hunter Biden served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company and was being paid a reported $50,000 per month. But there has been no evidence Hunter Biden was ever under investigation, and a variety of western bodies also wanted the former prosecutor to go for failing to root out corruption in Ukraine.

The House Committees of Foreign Affairs, Oversight, and Intelligence committees issued a subpoena f Giuliani to hand over communications and records.
description: Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham said he has invited the president's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani to testify due to the 'behavior' of the House of Representatives.
authors: Deputy U.S. Political Editor For Dailymail.Com
